Patch Set 48:

(6 comments)

The CI test failed because ‘pressingDuration’ was not declared in this scope, which is a new declared signal in phosphor-dbus-interfaces, so there's a dependency that this commit should be merged after the signal was added in commit below:
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/59703
Also https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/openbmc/+/60812
Could you add some more to this?
Revised, or would you like to reply about what kind of information supposed to be shown in commit message? thank you.
nit: camelCase
Revised, thank you for the correction.
so INSTANCES is a string like 012345?  Can you describe that in meson_options.txt?
Added, thank you for your suggestion.
Wrapping for commit messages should be 72 for the body (see https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#formatting-commit-messages)
Commit revised, thank you for your correction.
can you add what the new object paths you're adding are, and what the new behaviors are?
Commit revised, thank you for your suggestion.
may as well move this to the .cpp file

It seems that inline function can't move from header to src file.
I tried but encounter unsolvable error after compiling.

cppcheck complained about this:
cppcheck: Uninitialized variable: chassisNumFind
Corrected,thank you for your correction.
maybe, 'Timed required to be considered a longer press'.
Revised, thank you for your suggestion.
that is
Revised, thank you for your correction.
can you add a comment on why the host-selector button service can't be present for this to be done?
Comment added, thank you for your suggestion.
POWER_DBUS_OBJECT_NAME is /xyz/openbmc_project/Chassis/Buttons/Power0, so you're looking for a match on /xyz/openbmc_project/Chassis/Buttons/Power00, Power01, etc?
Exactly, those object paths were probed as each power button on sled or slot.
can remove.
Removed, thank you for your suggestion.

If it is a number, why is it a string?  Seems like a lousy API.

Change parameter name so it isn't tied to multi-chassis.  This can be reused for other purposes.

`index` as the name?
I'll force commit after revised and verified, thank you for your correction.
Revised and verified, thank you for your correction.

explicit ButtonIFRegister(size_t count)

1. Use explicit for single-parameter constructors.
2. Don't tie this to chassis.  We can have multiple buttons for other reasons.
3. Use size_t for things which are countable.
I'll force commit after revised and verified, thank you for your correction.
Revised and verified, thank you for your correction.
size_t
I'll force commit after revised and verified, thank you for your correction.
Revised and verified, thank you for your correction.
`size_t`, never int for countable things.
This is a very difficult to read for-loop.  Please refactor this function to be more obvious.
I'll force commit after revised and verified, thank you for your correction.
I'll force commit after revised and verified, thank you for your correction.
Revised and verified, thank you for your correction.
Revised and verified, thank you for your correction.

This `find` unfortunately matches "1" if the only instance is "10".  I'm not sure if that is what you intend.

Why do we require them to be in order?  You can have a system design with
4 slots, but knowingly takes double-width cards.  You might number them 1,3 for consistency with a system that takes single-width cards.  (Halfdome is exactly this design w.r.t. Yv3.5 chassis).

The contain of INSTANCES came from machine conf, it will be used in both phosphor-buttons and phosphor-state-manager so that no duplicate code was added, the in-order rules has been used since project Yosemitev2 and Bletchley.

After verified, the number "10" can be correctly parsed if the INSTANCE content follow the rule that deviding the in-order string with space as meson option's description shows.

If you turn INSTANCES into a vector of strings somewhere else, this becomes a lot easier.

```
return std::accumulate(std::begin(INSTANCES), std::end(INSTANCES), 0, [](auto m, auto s){ return std::max(m, std::atoi(s)); }); 
```
I'll force commit after tried and verified, thank you for your correction.
Revised and verified, thank you for your correction.
Don't embed the word 'chassis' so much in generic code.
I'll force commit after revised and verified, thank you for your correction.
Revised and verified, thank you for your correction.
`index`.
I'll force commit after revised and verified, thank you for your correction.
Revised and verified, thank you for your correction.
We got rid of "LONGER" in the dbus.  I think this meson update needs to be looked at.
I'll force commit after revised and verified, thank you for your correction.
Revised and verified as above, thank you for your correction.
Since INSTANCES is intended to be quoted, you can probably get the compiler to turn this into a vector<string> here.
I'll force commit after tried and verified, thank you for your correction.
Revised from function numberOfChassis() thank you for your correction.
Remove.
I'll force commit after revised and verified, thank you for your correction.
Rename to "multi-cycle-limit-ms" for identifying between power cycle and power off, thank you for your correction.
Need a default of 0?
The default value 0 was set in mesno.build.
We should not be listening to our own dbus signal here.  Calculate the released time in the released function.

Bus handler here has already creates all kinds of button matches including single power button, reset button, id button and host select button.

I'm not sure about whether I misunderstand your suggestion or not , would you like to design other way that entering event handler without all these matches in this commit? or to simplify commit's intention, it's more suitable to revise these matches in future change.
Tj

Matches were created for not only listening the signal that already with press duration from power_button.cpp 88 by follow former single-power button behavior (42~51), but also identifying the object path from signal's message.

I afraid that if these matches can't be used, the event handler in power_button.cpp needs more details for identifying which slot's button was trigger.

Bus handler here has already creates all kinds of button matches including single power button, reset button, id button and host select button.

I'm not sure about whether I misunderstand your suggestion or not , would you like to design other way that entering event handler without all these matches in this commit? or to simplify commit's intention, it's more suitable to revise these matches in future change.

I'm surprised it works, to be honest.  Usually you can't listen to signals from your own process in dbus...

Can leave it as is if you think it is working.
there's 2 applications in this repo:  'buttons' watches the GPIOs and emits signals.  'button-handler', this application, listens for the signals.
This implies chassis is a single-digit number.  Please don't make shortcuts like this.  We may want to support 16-slot chassis designs.
I'll force commit after revised and verified, thank you for your correction.
Revised and verified, thank you for your correction.

I don't understand why we're overwriting the string from 223.  If we got a signal for a specific path, shouldn't we handle that instead of worrying about the selector?  I'm confused by what this code is accomplishing now that you've added `chassisPath`.

To reserve the behavior of multi host system with host selector button like Yosemitev2, hostNumStr will be overwriting according to dbus service of host selector recorded if host selector button is used.
Can you leave some comments in the code to explain this, please?
I'll added the description, thank you for your suggestion.
Add description for two power button modes, thank you.
Can we save the results of this somewhere as a boolean?  You seem to be using it multiple times and each one of these are an expensive mapper lookup.
I'll force commit after revised and verified, thank you for your correction.
Revised and verified, thank you for your correction.
Remove "longer" support, right?
I'll force commit after revised and verified, thank you for your correction.
Revised and verified as above, thank you for your correction.
Need to get rid of "longer"?
I'll force commit after revised and verified, thank you for your correction.
Revised and verified as above, thank you for your correction.
If you need to start using the message, delete the commented out variable name.
I'll force commit after revised and verified, thank you for your correction.
Revised and verified, thank you for your correction.

I don't really like the way this is defined.  It doesn't seem like it really needs to be an option and it too hard-coded in the current implementation.

For a button, we have a set of <length, behavior>.  Whatever length of time a button is held for, we perform the behavior associated with that length.  We should probably make that some sort of json config rather than a bunch of compile-time options.

There's some point of view, would you please to to confirm them?

1. Former projects' button json conf have already set and added from their own corresponding project layer. To avoid that former projects crashed without the option "long-press-time-ms", this option needs to be kept instead changing all former projects' json conf.

2. So far, button conf is parsed from buttons, so adding json parsing when starting button handlder insteat transfer the  
so that button handler

After I'm reading the code, it isn't obvious to me why we need to introduce a new meson option for this.  You have a JSON configuration file.  Can't you determine from the configuration file if it is single-host or multi-host?
Revised, thank you for reviewing.

The reason using meson option "host-instance" is that the partition about creating ButtonRegister(L22~24) in power_button.cpp is prior to any runtime-parsing about gpio_conf, it is used for create multiple button object for pressing signal, not for distinguishing between single-host or multi-host. In fact, most of former project were using single power button even it's multi-host.
Please drop `0` since this is an invalid configuration to have 0 in a multi-host system.
Revised, thank you for reviewing.
`auto* INSTANCES`?
Why does it need to be static if it is inline?

If the `@INSTANCES@` value, which comes from the meson option, had commas already we could turn this into an array without any parsing at all.

```
constexpr inline static auto INSTANCES = std::to_array({ @INSTANCES@ });
```

This would require the meson option to be something like `1, 2, 3, 4`.
It would build failed after changed into auto ptr.
